Title: Show that $\int_0^{\pi/3} \big((\sqrt{3}\cos x-\sin x)\sin x\big)^{1/2}\cos x \,dx =\frac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8\sqrt{2}}. $
Content:
I have run a FORTRAN code and I have obtained strong evidence that
$$\int_0^{\pi/3} \!\!
\big((\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta-\sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta\big)^{\!1/2}\!\cos\vartheta \,d\vartheta
=\frac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8\sqrt{2}}. 
$$
In fact, it looks like my numerical integration method (the trapezoid rule) converges to the value $\dfrac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8\sqrt{2}}$, with at least $12$ significant digits. Any ideas how to prove this result analytically?
llm_answer_create_structured_problem:
###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
ϑ is a real variable in the interval $[0, \pi/3]$,
The integrand is $\sqrt{(\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta - \sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta} \cdot \cos\vartheta$,
The expression $(\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta - \sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta$ is non-negative for all $\vartheta$ in $[0, \pi/3]$.
Problem:
Show that 
$$\int_0^{\pi/3} \!\!
\big((\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta-\sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta\big)^{\!1/2}\!\cos\vartheta \,d\vartheta
=\frac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8\sqrt{2}}.$$
###

Original_Problem_with_numerical_assumpti:
Assumption:
Assumption 1: ϑ is a real variable in the interval $[0, \pi/3]$,
Assumption 2: The integrand is $\sqrt{(\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta - \sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta} \cdot \cos\vartheta$,
Assumption 3: The expression $(\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta - \sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta$ is non-negative for all $\vartheta$ in $[0, \pi/3]$.
Problem:
Show that 
$$\int_0^{\pi/3} \!\!
\big((\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta-\sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta\big)^{\!1/2}\!\cos\vartheta \,d\vartheta
=\frac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8\sqrt{2}}.$$
Problem_with_redundant_assumption:
Assumption:
Assumption 1: ϑ is a real variable in the interval $[0, \pi/3]$,
Assumption 2: The integrand is $\sqrt{(\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta - \sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta} \cdot \cos\vartheta$,
Assumption 3: The expression $(\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta - \sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta$ is non-negative for all $\vartheta$ in $[0, \pi/3]$.
Assumption 4: $$
\begin{align}
(\sqrt{3}\cos(\theta)-\sin(\theta))\sin(\theta)
&=2\sin(\tfrac\pi3-\theta)\sin(\theta)\\
&=\cos(\tfrac\pi3-2\theta)-\cos(\tfrac\pi3)\\
&=\tfrac12-2\sin^2(\tfrac\pi6-\theta)\\
&=\tfrac12-2\sin^2(\theta-\tfrac\pi6)\tag{1}
\end{align}
$$
Problem:
Show that 
$$\int_0^{\pi/3} \!\!
\big((\sqrt{3}\cos\vartheta-\sin\vartheta)\sin\vartheta\big)^{\!1/2}\!\cos\vartheta \,d\vartheta
=\frac{\pi\sqrt{3}}{8\sqrt{2}}.$$
